awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Form and function of the hip joint and pelvis in relationship to walking biomechanics and implications for the evolution of bipedalism
awd_abstract_narration:
Walking on two legs – also known as bipedalism – is a hallmark of the human lineage. It remains unclear whether and how the types of bipedalism in humans’ earliest ancestors differed from that in modern humans. This doctoral dissertation research uses 3D motion analysis to investigate how variation in the appearance of the lower limb skeleton is related to biomechanical performance while walking on two legs. In addition to direct observation, this project also experimentally tests the effects of hominin skeletal anatomy on bipedal performance. This transformational approach aims to produce a validated methodological framework for future research into the diversity of locomotor behavior in hominins. The project's anticipated outcomes include a large dataset of interest and use to anthropologists, clinical and functional anatomists, physical therapists, and other clinicians, and a new, open-source tool for measuring skeletal features that can be used by anthropologists, morphologists, and clinicians. This project supports the work of an early career scientist from a group underrepresented in STEM and provides training opportunities for undergraduates in biological anthropology, anatomy, radiology, 3D motion analysis, and more.

While Australopithecus and early Homo are widely agreed to have been habitual bipeds, the form of bipedality in different hominin species and the timing of emergence of a human-like striding bipedal gait remain a subject of debate. Pelvic morphology and torsion in the lower limb bones vary among hominin taxa, and because this variation is associated with variation in the biomechanics of bipedalism in living humans, there is a unique opportunity to test hypothesized gait differences in Australopithecus and early Homo compared to later hominins. This doctoral dissertation research uses a combination of ultra-low dose standing biplanar radiographs and 3D motion analysis in a sample of living humans to quantify variation in pelvic and lower limb skeletal torsion and determine the effects of skeletal torsion across the lower limb on locomotor performance in vivo. This study integrates a novel method for measuring skeletal morphology of living subjects in 3D with established approaches to motion analysis to explore fundamental questions in functional morphology and human evolution. These findings can better characterize the functional significance of skeletal variation and its implications for understanding the diversity of locomotor behavior in hominins, as well as provide a lens through which to interpret the role of locomotion in hominin evolution, which are argued to be critical to the evolution of the genus Homo.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Upright bipedal walking is a hallmark of the human lineage and a key feature distinguishing hominins (those organisms more closely related to humans than to our closest living relatives, the chimpanzees and bonobos) from other primates. However, the timing of the emergence of a human-like striding bipedal gait in the hominin lineage has long been a subject of debate. These questions have been further complicated by recent evidence that multiple hominin species may have been present in eastern Africa by as early as 3.5 million years ago, and that they may have engaged in different locomotor behaviors. The scarcity of associated remains in the fossil record, though, has provided limited data with which to evaluate hypotheses of locomotor diversity early in human evolution. This project used standing bi-planar x-ray imaging and 3D motion analysis to directly investigate how the shape of the bones in the pelvis and lower limbs is related to walking biomechanics in living human participants. This transformational approach aims to produce an experimentally validated methodological framework for interpreting variation on hominin skeletal morphology and testing hypotheses of hominin locomotor diversity. 

 

The goals of this project were (1) to determine how torsion (twisting) in the pelvis and lower limb bones, which may affect the orientations of articular surfaces in the hip, knee, and ankle joints, varies across the lower limb, (2) how torsion in one limb segment is related to torsion in others, and (3) how, either individually or in combination, these skeletal torsion features affect walking biomechanics. 

 

The study produced several key findings that may have significant implications for interpretations of locomotor diversity in the hominin fossil record. First, we found that the hip joint is more forward-facing in humans and fossil hominins than in other primates, which is probably related to bipedal walking in the human lineage. Second, torsion in the femur (thighbone) is correlated with torsion in the tibia (shinbone), such that torsion in one element may compensate for effects of torsion in the other to produce a foot that is pointed forward during walking. Third, greater values of femoral anteversion, i.e., high levels of torsion in the femur that would produce a more forward-facing hip relative to the knee, are associated with more externally rotated iliac blades. This pattern might suggest that torsion in the femur is a mechanism for maintaining the positions of important muscle attachments on the femur and pelvis relative to the hip joint. Finally, we found that despite substantial variation in lower limb skeletal torsion, these morphologies are not significantly correlated with biomechanical variables such as pelvic or lower limb rotation about an axial plane in this sample during level overground walking. This suggests that either greater morphological disparity is required to observe significant differences in locomotor kinematics, or that other mechanisms, such as variation in timing and intensity of muscle activation during walking, may compensate for effects of morphological variation to produce a similar functional outcome among individuals. Further work is currently underway to investigate these possibilities and their implications for interpretations of hominin locomotor behavior and evolution.

 

Intellectual Merit: 

This project is a critical first step toward developing a new, experimentally validated framework for interpreting locomotor behavior in fossil hominins. This study directly tests form-function relationships in the lower limb that are hypothesized to be critical to bipedal walking performance in an experimental system that is directly applicable to fossil hominins, which will facilitate improved inferences about fossil hominin behavior, ecology, and evolution from the limited available fossil record. The initial results of this study demonstrate that, within living humans, variation in skeletal morphology does not necessarily imply variation in locomotor kinematics. These findings suggest that caution is warranted in interpretations of musculoskeletal function and performance based on skeletal morphology alone, especially in anatomical regions that are highly variable. 

 

Broader Impacts: 

This award supported the research and professional development of an early career scientist and provided research and training for multiple undergraduate students. Data collected during this study will provide new research and training opportunities to multiple undergraduates, medical students, and allied health students in the coming years. Finally, this study produced a dataset of biplanar x-rays and 3D motion analysis data for a sample representing 28 healthy young adult individuals. Once results of this study are published, the de-identified x-ray and motion analysis data will be made freely available to other researchers. This open-access dataset will provide new opportunities for other researchers to test hypotheses about form-function relationships in the pelvis and lower limb skeletal using data that has already been collected and will provide an educational resource for anthropologists, anatomists, and healthcare professionals.
